headline: Tokenized assets expected to grow to $19T by 2033. Here's how.
summary: The tokenization of real-world assets (RWA) is on the rise as trading platforms like Robinhood Markets (HOOD) begin offering tokenized stocks to overseas investors. Yahoo Finance senior business reporter Ines Ferré explains tokenization and breaks down the Wall Street forecasts anticipating the market cap for tokenized assets to explode within the next 8 years. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Asking for a Trend.

headline: Cantor Fitzgerald Raises the Firm’s PT on Robinhood Markets (HOOD), Keeps a Buy
summary: Robinhood Markets, Inc. (NASDAQ:HOOD) is one of the Best Performing Financial Stocks So Far in 2025. On September 12, Brett Knoblauch from Cantor Fitzgerald raised the firm’s price target on Robinhood Markets, Inc. (NASDAQ:HOOD) from $128 to $130, while reiterating a Buy rating on the stock. The bullish sentiment comes after the company released its […]

headline: Here’s What Lifted Robinhood Markets (HOOD) in Q2
summary: ClearBridge Investments, an investment management company, released its “ClearBridge Growth Strategy” second-quarter 2025 investor letter. A copy of the letter can be downloaded here. US equities significantly rallied in the second quarter, with the S&P 500 returning 10.9%. As the risk-on sentiment took hold, the benchmark Russell Midcap Growth Index advanced a market-leading 18.2%. Growth stocks […]

headline: Dow Jones Futures Await Fed Rate Cut, Powell; Nvidia Falls On China Ban Report
summary: The stock market awaits a rate cut and Fed chief Powell. Nvidia fell on a reported China ban. Meta and Palantir are near buy points.

headline: The Bulls Are Back. This ETF Stands to Gain.
summary: We had been measured ahead of the Fed meeting. Now that risks seem to be easing, it makes it easier to have conviction that stocks can advance in a lower-rate environment.

headline: 1 Cash-Heavy Stock to Own for Decades and 2 We Find Risky
summary: A cash-heavy balance sheet is often a sign of strength, but not always. Some companies avoid debt because they have weak business models, limited expansion opportunities, or inconsistent cash flow.
